block.p: International A3-17 U.S. SEEKS NATO BOSNIA FORCE The U.S. is urging allies to prepare an international force that would be sent the Bosnia immediately after a peace settlement there, but planning is being hampered by a dispute between the U.S. and France over who would command it. A1 The U.N. military chief in Bosnia is headed for besieged enclave. A16

International A3-17 U.S. SEEKS NATO BOSNIA FORCE The U.S. is urging allies to prepare an international force that would be sent the Bosnia immediately after a peace settlement there, but planning is being hampered by a dispute between the U.S. and France over who would command it. A1 The U.N. military chief in Bosnia is headed for besieged enclave. A16

Bosnia's President delayed his return to talks in New York. A17 SHOULD YELTSIN BE U.S. FOCUS? News analysis: The Administration's campaign to help Boris Yeltsin comes as his political future is again precarious and he is engaged once again in the trenches with a hostile Russian Congress. A1 Boris Yeltsin won a crucial vote in the Russian Congress. A14 EGYPT KILLS 21 MILITANTS Egyptian security forces killed 21 people and wounded two dozen in nine raids in Cairo and Aswan against Islamic militants seeking to overthrow the Government. A1 STRICT ABORTION LAW IN POLAND The Polish Government gazette will soon publish the latest laws approved by Parliament. Two weeks later Poland will have the most restrictive law on abortion of any country in Eastern Europe. A3 PALESTINIANS REJECT INVITATION Palestinian leaders rejected an invitation to a new round of Middle East peace talks, citing Israel's deportation of Muslim fundamentalists, but did not rule out ultimately rejoining the negotiations. A8 LIBERIAN REBELS ON THE RUN After three years of warfare in Liberia, the rebel leader Charles Taylor's military position is deteriorating rapidly, reports from West Africa and U.S. officials say. A10 BRITISH PREMIER UNDER SIEGE The British Prime Minister's grip on government has slipped, strained by a growing rebellion within his party over Europe and deepening public dismay over his failure to revive the country's moribund economy. A15 DOUBT ON ITALY'S FUTURE News Analysis: The bribery and corruption scandal enveloping Italy has struck both the public and private sectors, undermining both and casting doubt on the nation's future. A6 GAINS AGAINST BASQUE REBELS A string of arrests of leading guerrillas in France has stirred cautious optimism in Spain that the end of the Basque terrorist movement may finally be in sight. A5 The former chief of the East German secret police is on trial. A4 President Suharto was re-elected to a sixth five-year term. A13 Beijing is going all out to be host of the Olympics in 2000. A12 National A18-21, B10-13 JUDGE RULES ON HEALTH PANEL A Federal judge ruled that Hillary Rodham Clinton's health panel must announce its meetings and open some to the public, but can meet privately when formulating recommendations. A1 A committee approved of Janet Reno as Attorney General. A21 Democrats won a first round for Clinton's deficit plans. A20 Aspin could be on a collision course with the Joint Chiefs. A20 Clinton plans an effort to cushion the affects of base closings. A20 ABORTION DOCTOR IS KILLED An anti-abortion demonstrator shot and killed a doctor during a protest outside his clinic, then surrendered, the police said. A1 NEGOTIATING WITH A 'MESSIAH' Like a game of three-dimensional chess, conversations between Federal agents and the leader of the cult in Waco veer from haggles over milk to Biblical discourses. After 11 days, the agents have no idea what he wants. A1 KING ADMITS LYING Rodney G. King conceded that he had lied about his beating and that he was not really sure whether the officers who beat him had used racial epithets or threatened to kill him, as he had testified. A18 The retrial of a Miami police officer is moved again. A18 N.A.A.C.P. LOOKS AT JACKSON As the N.A.A.C.P., searches for a new executive director, the possibility of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's getting the job is a hot topic at the association. A18 HOUSING AGENCY UNDER FIRE Four years after HUD became a symbol of ineptitude and graft, a succession of reports has warned that another scandal "is a distinct possibility." A21 The chief of the Federal Centers for Disease Control quits. B12 Astronomers clock a star moving faster than any ever seen. B13 New evidence that opening plugged arteries with balloons works. B13 Debunking an AIDS myth about recreational drug use. B13 Metro Digest B1 ANOTHER ARREST IN BOMBING A chemical engineer of Palestinian descent, who had studied the principles of explosives, was arrested and charged yesterday with aiding in the World Trade Center bombing. A1 TRACING THE MONEY TRAIL Federal investigators say they believe that money used to finance the bombing of the World Trade Center was transferred in recent months from Europe to a New Jersey bank account used by the two suspects now under arrest. A1 Business Digest D1 Home Section C1-13 Designed with tongue in chic. C1 At home with Michael Douglas. C1 Breast-feeding strategies for busy mothers. C1 Shopping for a dictionary? C2 Currents C3 Review/Fashion: In Milan, a costume party. C6 Review/Fashion: Sexy Austerity from Jil Sander. C6 Parent & Child C12 Arts/Entertainment C15-24 Italian cinema's everyman. C15 For Rolf Hochhuth, a new play, a new furor. C15 Arts grants for New York City groups. C20 Music: Gang of Four returns. C15 Dance: Premiere of Merce Cunningham's "Enter." C15 Word and Image: Home Video C18 Sports B14-19 Baseball: Meet the new Bonilla. B15 Abbott hopes for long-term stay. B19 Basketball: Much to prove in Big East. B15 Nets defeat Clippers. B18 Close-game drills for Knicks. B18 Column: Anderson on Manhattan College. B15 Football: Giants pool for free agents. B15 Hockey: Rangers out of sick bay. B19 Islanders lose to Canadiens. B14 Obituaries D23 Andrea Boroff Eagan, a writer and women's advocate.
Don Barksdale, one of the first blacks to play in the N.B.A.
Max A. Zorn; developed a theory that changed math.

Editorials/Op-Ed A22-23 Editorials The Republicans strike back. More Twin Tower mysteries. Bungee jumping at the U.N. Letters William Safire: Communostalgia. Leslie H. Gelb: Where's Bill? Garrison Keillor: Notes on a new and improved era. Linda Aiken and Claire Fagin: More nurses, better medicine.
